awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Cascadia2020: Investigating subduction zone segmentation with a 3D high-resolution Vp model
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cascadia subduction zone is known to generate infrequent (every ~500 years) but potentially very large (up to magnitude 9) earthquakes. The most recent such earthquake occurred on January 26th, 1700, and GPS data acquired during the last two decades suggest that strain is accumulating across the subduction zone fault in preparation for a future earthquake. However, there is considerable uncertainty about how the geologic structure of the subduction zone will impact strain release during a Cascadia earthquake. Different plausible earthquake scenarios result in quite different predicted ground shaking, which in turn influences building codes and emergency response plans. This project will image the structure of the crust in the region where large Cascadia earthquakes are thought to occur. The objective is to understand three-dimensional variations in seismic velocity in order to provide insights into the factors that control segmentation of slip during earthquakes and the resulting amplitude of ground shaking in populated areas and sedimentary basins. With its large footprint and involvement of many field hands, this project will provide student research experiences and opportunities for public outreach and education about geohazards in the Pacific Northwest. This project is a collaboration between Oregon State University, University of Oregon, Eugene, South Dakota School of Mines and Technology and the U.S. Geological Survey.

This project has the ultimate goal of generating a high-resolution model of an active subduction system that will span the Cascadia plate boundary, including the transition between major along-strike segments, and cross the transition from the nominally locked zone down-dip to depths where plate motion is accommodated by episodic tremor and slip. A dense network of temporary short-period seismometers along the coast of the Pacific Northwest will extend high resolution imaging of the structure of the overlying and down-going plates, as well as the thickness and characteristics of material within the plate interface zone, to depths that are critical for understanding earthquake processes. The array design includes a single deployment of three-component instruments at 1-km intervals along the onshore extension of dip lines embedded within a sparser grid of seismometers spaced 7-10 km apart for a total of ~700 three-component seismic stations. To tie results from the seismogenic part of the plate boundary to larger-scale forearc and arc structure, two profiles will extend across the forearc. All stations will record natural sources as well as man-made sources for the duration of the deployment. The seismic data from this experiment will be made immediately available to the community. The resulting high-resolution 3D Vp model will also be made accessible and is critical for constraining analyses of seismic noise, magnetotelluric and potential field data, as well as for improving predictions of earthquake ground shaking and tsunami generation in the Pacific Northwest.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project represents a collaboration between the University of Oregon, Oregon State University, The United States Geological Survey, and the South Dakota School of Mines & Technology with the main aim of better understanding the subsurface beneath the coastline along western Oregon and Washington, USA. To achieve this, researchers and student volunteers from around the county helped to deploy hundreds of temporary seismometers in the summers of 2021 and 2022 along the western Cascadia margin. These seismometers recorded both natural and human-made seismic sources that can be used to image the Earth in much the same way a Computed Tomography (CT) scan can reveal what the inside of a human looks like. The array of seismometers used in this study allowed for a much more detailed imaging of the Earth than previous studies have been able to perform because of the dense station spacing or small distances between seismometers; in some cases, less than a kilometer. With this data, both travel time and scattered wave images were produced from the surface to depths of about 100 kilometers. Travel time tomography measures how long it takes seismic waves to move though the Earth and scattered wave imaging measures how seismic waves refract or bend when they travel though changes in seismic velocity. With these seismic techniques, a more detailed subducting slab model was produced. Locating the top of the subducting Juan de Fuca slab is important because the largest megathrust earthquakes are generated along the plate boundary between the Juan de Fuca plate and the North American plate. Having a better sense of where this plate interface is located in space will allow subsequent researchers the opportunity to model different earthquake scenarios along the Cascadia margin with more realistic parameters, leading to improved earthquake hazard maps. The data collected in this project has also been archived and is available for future researchers to integrate into larger regional scale seismic velocity models.  


Last Modified: 05/30/2024
Modified by: Kevin M Ward
